    Ok, great. How could I write this updateHpBar function to return a promise? function updateHpBar(player, currentHp, maxHp) { let currentPlayer = player; let progressBar = document.getElementById(`hp-bar-${currentPlayer}`); let hpPercentage = (currentHp / maxHp) * 100; progressBar.style.width = `${hpPercentage}%`; console.log("HPBAR UPDATED:" + hpPercentage); }
    1 / 1

    In order to make updateHpBar return a Promise, you can create a new Promise within the function. Inside this Promise, you could use setTimeout to emulate the delay you want for the animation. Since we cannot detect when a CSS transition finishes directly in JavaScript, we set the timeout to be the same duration as your transition.

    Here's an example how you could do it:

    javascript
    function updateHpBar(player, currentHp, maxHp) {
  let currentPlayer = player;
  let progressBar = document.getElementById(`hp-bar-${currentPlayer}`);
  let hpPercentage = (currentHp / maxHp) * 100;
  progressBar.style.width = `${hpPercentage}%`;
  console.log("HPBAR UPDATED:" + hpPercentage);

  return new Promise(resolve => {
    setTimeout(() => {
      resolve();
    }, 1000); // same duration as your transition
  });
}

    In this code, updateHpBar now returns a Promise that resolves after a 1-second timeout. This means you can use await updateHpBar(player, currentHp, maxHp); in an async function to pause execution until the "animation" is complete.

    Do remember to adjust the timeout duration to match your actual CSS transition duration.

    This is a workaround and is not always precise because JavaScript's setTimeout is not guaranteed to run exactly as specified, it just guarantees that it won't run sooner than specified. In other words, if your JavaScript runtime is busy doing other things when the timeout expires, the Promise won't resolve until it gets around to processing it.

    If you want more precise control over animations, you might want to use an animation library that provides JavaScript callbacks for animation events, or the Web Animations API, which is a native browser API.

    Ok, how can I disable all of a menus buttons while a player's chosen move is being executed? For example, in a function like this one, how can I make it so all buttons become disabled after onclick? function showAttackMenu() { const attackMenu = document.getElementById("main-menu"); const attacks = battle.currentTurn.currentMonster.moves; // Clear out the existing menu attackMenu.innerHTML = ""; // For each attack, create a button, add the onclick, and append it to the menu attacks.forEach((attack) => { let attackButton = document.createElement("button"); attackButton.innerText = `${attack.name}, ${attack.currentUsage}/${attack.maxUsage}`; attackButton.onclick = function () { if (attack.isUsable()) { attack.use(); handleAttack(attack); } else { displayMessage("You can't use that move anymore."); } }; attackMenu.appendChild(attackButton); }); let backButton = document.createElement("button"); backButton.innerText = "Back"; backButton.onclick = function () { showMainMenu(); }; attackMenu.appendChild(backButton); }
    1 / 1

    To disable all buttons, you need to have a reference to them. In your case, it's probably best to store all buttons in an array when creating them. Then, you can loop over that array and disable all the buttons before handleAttack(attack) and enable them again after the attack is done.

    Here's how you could implement that:

    javascript
    let buttons = [];

function disableButtons() {
  buttons.forEach(button => button.disabled = true);
}

function enableButtons() {
  buttons.forEach(button => button.disabled = false);
}

function showAttackMenu() {
  const attackMenu = document.getElementById("main-menu");
  const attacks = battle.currentTurn.currentMonster.moves;

  // Clear out the existing menu
  attackMenu.innerHTML = "";

  // Clear out existing buttons
  buttons = [];

  // For each attack, create a button, add the onclick, and append it to the menu
  attacks.forEach((attack) => {
    let attackButton = document.createElement("button");
    attackButton.innerText = `${attack.name}, ${attack.currentUsage}/${attack.maxUsage}`;
    attackButton.onclick = function () {
      if (attack.isUsable()) {
        attack.use();
        disableButtons();  // Disable buttons here
        handleAttack(attack);
      } else {
        displayMessage("You can't use that move anymore.");
      }
    };
    attackMenu.appendChild(attackButton);
    buttons.push(attackButton); // Store button reference
  });

  let backButton = document.createElement("button");
  backButton.innerText = "Back";
  backButton.onclick = function () {
    showMainMenu();
  };
  attackMenu.appendChild(backButton);
  buttons.push(backButton); // Store button reference
}

    In your handleAttack(attack) function, you would then call enableButtons() at the end to re-enable the buttons once the action is done.

    Remember that this is a simple way of doing this, and depending on your game's complexity you might need a more sophisticated approach. This will work fine for disabling and enabling all buttons, but if you want to enable or disable individual buttons based on certain conditions, you might want to store more information or use a more complex data structure to keep track of your buttons.

    In CSS, the :disabled pseudo-class provides a way to style a disabled control. In this case, you can add a new CSS rule to disable the hover effect and change the button color when the button is disabled. Here's how:

    css
    .actions button {

    color: #666666;
    border: none;

    This will give disabled buttons a grey color and remove the border on hover. You can customize these styles as you see fit for your game.

    Ok, that works great. Let's say I want to continue developing the game using Phaser.js; how would I install the library so that it's available when I deploy the game?
    1 / 1

    To use Phaser.js for game development, you will need to include it in your project.

    Phaser can be added to your project in two main ways: by including it using a CDN, or by installing it via npm. The method you choose depends on the setup of your project.

    1. Using a CDN:

      You can include Phaser in your HTML file using a CDN like so:

      html
      <script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/phaser@3.55.2/dist/phaser.min.js"></script>

      Replace the version number (3.55.2 as of the time of writing) with the version you wish to use.

      This method is the easiest to get started with, but it may not be ideal for larger projects or for projects that are intended to be worked on offline.

    2. Using npm:

      If you're using npm for your project, you can install Phaser using the following command:

      npm install phaser

      After installing Phaser with npm, you can import it into your JavaScript files using require (if you're using Node.js):

      javascript
      const Phaser = require('phaser');

      or import (if you're using ES6 modules):

      javascript
      import Phaser from 'phaser';

      This method is better for larger projects or for projects where you're already using npm.

    In terms of deployment, if you use a CDN, you won't need to worry about including Phaser in your deployment as the Phaser library is pulled from the CDN at runtime.

    If you install Phaser via npm, you'll need to ensure that your deployment process includes running npm install to install all dependencies (including Phaser), or that you bundle your JavaScript using a tool like Webpack or Parcel, which will include Phaser in the bundle.

    1 / 1
    I've seen considerable discussion of TypeScript. What is the difference between this and regular JavaScript and would it make sense to use it for this game?
    1 / 1

    TypeScript is a superset of JavaScript, which means that any valid JavaScript code is also valid TypeScript code. TypeScript adds static types to JavaScript, which can help catch potential bugs early during development, provide more robust tooling (like autocompletion), and make it easier to reason about the code and its behavior.

    The main differences between TypeScript and JavaScript are:

    1. Static Typing: JavaScript is a dynamically typed language, which means that variables can hold values of any type and types can be changed throughout the lifetime of a variable. TypeScript introduces optional static typing which can catch type-related errors at compile time, before the code is run. This can prevent a whole class of bugs that are common in JavaScript.

    2. Interfaces and Types: TypeScript allows for better code structuring through the use of interfaces and types. This can be very useful for large projects or when working in teams.

    3. Support for future JavaScript features: TypeScript supports new and upcoming JavaScript features like decorators or async/await before they are fully supported in all major JavaScript environments.

    Using TypeScript for your game can be a good idea, especially as your codebase grows. It can make it easier to organize your code, and the static typing can prevent certain bugs. The main drawback is that there is a learning curve to TypeScript, and you will need to set up a compilation step to convert your TypeScript code into JavaScript that can be run in the browser.

    However, Phaser.js supports TypeScript out of the box, so if you decide to use TypeScript, you can benefit from Phaser's TypeScript definitions, which can make the development process smoother and less error-prone.

    In conclusion, whether you choose to use TypeScript or not depends on your personal preferences, your familiarity with TypeScript, and the size and complexity of your project. Both JavaScript and TypeScript can be used to make great games with Phaser.js!

    Ok. I've included Phaser.js through CDN. My next step is to build an intro animation that automatically triggers on load and resolves to a title menu. The player then chooses "Single Player" to be launched into the game itself. How would I do that?
    1 / 1

    Creating an intro animation and a title menu in Phaser can be broken down into several steps. Here is a simplified guide to get you started:

    1. Setting up your scenes: In Phaser, different parts of your game are usually encapsulated into different scenes. In your case, you would have at least two scenes: IntroScene and TitleScene. Each scene is a JavaScript class that extends Phaser.Scene.
    javascript
    class IntroScene extends Phaser.Scene {
    constructor() {
        super({ key: 'IntroScene' });
    }

    preload() {
        // load assets here
    }

    create() {
        // create animation here
    }
}

class TitleScene extends Phaser.Scene {
    constructor() {
        super({ key: 'TitleScene' });
    }

    create() {
        // create menu here
    }
}
    1. Setting up your game config: When you initialize your Phaser game, you can provide a config object. One of the properties of this object is scene, which can be an array of your scenes.
    javascript
    const config = {
    type: Phaser.AUTO,
    width: 800,
    height: 600,
    scene: [IntroScene, TitleScene]
};

const game = new Phaser.Game(config);
    1. Creating your intro animation: This will depend on what kind of animation you want to create. You can add sprites and apply tweens to them, or you can load a spritesheet and create an animation from it.
    javascript
    this.load.spritesheet('intro', 'assets/intro.png', { frameWidth: 64, frameHeight: 64 });

this.anims.create({
    key: 'introAnimation',
    frames: this.anims.generateFrameNumbers('intro', { start: 0, end: 50 }),
    frameRate: 10,
    repeat: -1
});

const introSprite = this.add.sprite(400, 300, 'intro');

introSprite.play('introAnimation');
    1. Switching to the title scene: You can use Phaser's time events to wait for a certain amount of time before switching to the title scene. Alternatively, you can check in your update function whether the animation has completed, and then switch to the title scene.
    javascript
    this.time.delayedCall(5000, () => {
    this.scene.start('TitleScene');
});
    1. Creating your title menu: In the create function of your TitleScene, you can add text objects that represent the menu items. You can set the interactive property of these text objects to true to make them interactive. You can then add click event listeners to these text objects.
    javascript
    const singlePlayerText = this.add.text(100, 100, 'Single Player', { fill: '#0f0' })
    .setInteractive()
    .on('pointerdown', () => { /* start game */ });

    Please note that the code snippets provided are simplified and will need to be adapted to your specific needs. For more detailed information on how to use Phaser, you may want to check out the official Phaser 3 examples and the Phaser 3 API documentation.

    Ok, and how would I integrate the existing JavaScript I have in my moves.js and game.js files into the Phaser framework?
    1 / 1

    You have a few options to integrate your existing code into the Phaser framework:

    1. As a Scene: You can wrap your game logic into a Phaser Scene. This is the most straightforward way if your game is already a complete, standalone entity. The create method would initialize your game, and the update method would contain the game loop logic.

    2. As a GameObject: If your game logic revolves around a specific object or set of objects (like players or monsters), you could consider turning these into Phaser GameObjects. This would involve extending Phaser.GameObjects.Sprite (or another suitable class) and implementing your logic there.

    3. As a Plugin: If your game logic is more global and doesn't naturally fit into a Scene or GameObject, you could consider creating a Phaser Plugin. A Plugin is a way to provide additional functionality to the entire game, and can interact with Phaser's internal systems directly.

    How you proceed will depend on how your code is currently structured and how tightly-coupled the various components are. Here's a basic example of how you might wrap your existing game logic in a Phaser Scene:

    javascript
    class MainGameScene extends Phaser.Scene {
    constructor() {
        super({ key: 'MainGameScene' });
    }

    create() {
        // Call your existing game's initialization code here
        game.init();
    }

    update() {
        // Call your existing game's update loop code here
        game.update();
    }
}

    In this case, game would be an instance of whatever class or object you have that encapsulates your game logic in your game.js file.

    Note that Phaser has its own game loop, so if your code contains its own game loop, you will need to refactor that code to work within Phaser's update method, which is called every frame.

    You may also need to refactor other parts of your code to work within Phaser. For example, if you're manually manipulating the DOM for your game's UI, you might want to switch to using Phaser's built-in methods for rendering text, images, etc.

    The specifics will depend on your code, but generally, you'll want to work within Phaser's system as much as possible, as this will make it easier to take advantage of Phaser's features and performance optimizations.

    1 / 1
    What if my game does have its own loop? Right now the functions just call each other appropriately depending on player actions with a few async functions to adjust pacing.
    1 / 1

    If your game has its own loop, it might not fit perfectly into Phaser's update loop since Phaser's loop is designed to be executed every frame, and it's not necessarily designed to wait for asynchronous operations. However, this doesn't mean you can't work with Phaser; you'll just need to think a little differently about how your game logic fits into Phaser's loop.

    One approach you could take is to let Phaser handle the frame-by-frame rendering, and let your own game logic continue to control the flow of the game. You can do this by creating a separate "game controller" object that interacts with Phaser and your game code. Here's a rough idea of what this might look like:

    javascript
    class GameController {
    constructor(scene, game) {
        this.scene = scene;
        this.game = game;
        this.playerActionPending = false;
    }

    playerDidAction(action) {
        this.playerActionPending = true;
        this.currentAction = action;
    }

    update() {
        if (this.playerActionPending) {
            this.game.executeAction(this.currentAction);
            this.playerActionPending = false;
        }
    }
}

class MainGameScene extends Phaser.Scene {
    constructor() {
        super({ key: 'MainGameScene' });
    }

    create() {
        // Initialize your game
        const game = new Game();
        
        // Create a controller and pass it the Phaser scene and your game
        this.controller = new GameController(this, game);

        // Listen for a player action and tell the controller when it happens
        this.input.on('pointerup', function (pointer) {
            this.controller.playerDidAction('attack');  // or whatever action the player did
        }, this);
    }

    update() {
        // Let the controller handle the update
        this.controller.update();
    }
}

    In this code, the GameController is the intermediary between Phaser and your game code. When the player does an action (like clicking the mouse), the Phaser scene tells the GameController, which then tells your game to execute the action. The GameController's update method checks to see if an action is pending, and if so, it executes it in your game.

    Again, this is a rough example, and the specifics will depend on how your code is structured and what kind of player actions and game updates you have. The important concept is that you're using Phaser's loop to handle rendering and user input, and using your own loop to handle game logic, with a controller object serving as the intermediary between the two.

    Ah, sorry, I meant what if my game *doesn't* have its own loop.
    1 / 1

    If your game doesn't have its own loop and largely depends on events and asynchronous operations, that's perfectly fine! Phaser is flexible enough to accommodate such a structure.

    While Phaser does have an inherent game loop that it uses for updating animations, physics, and more on a frame-by-frame basis, you're not required to use it if it doesn't fit your game's structure.

    Phaser's Scenes have several key methods that you can use to structure your game:

    1. init(): This method is called once when the Scene is started. You can use it to prepare the data needed in the Scene.

    2. preload(): This method is also called once at the start of the Scene. It is used to load external files such as images, audio files, spritesheets, etc.

    3. create(): This method is called once all the assets in the preload method have been loaded. It is used to add objects to your game.

    4. update(): This method is called every frame and is usually used for updating the game state.

    If your game's flow is based more around events and async operations rather than a continuous loop, you'll likely be using the create() method for setting up initial game state and setting up event handlers. For example, button clicks and other player inputs can be handled here.

    javascript
    class MyScene extends Phaser.Scene {
  create() {
    // You can create a button and then provide a callback function
    // that will be called when the button is clicked
    let button = this.add.image(100, 100, 'button');
    button.setInteractive();
    button.on('pointerdown', () => {
      // This is where you put what happens when the button is clicked
    });

    // Here you can also start your battle system, etc.
  }
}

    In such a structure, the Phaser Scene is more like a "stage" where different parts of your game (like the battle system, or a dialogue system, etc.) are started and stopped.

    Your existing async functions can likely stay the way they are, being called as a result of events like a player making a choice, an animation finishing, etc.

    Ok, before I start the Phaser integration, my friend made me a short 42 second wav file for the battle scene. How can I make it play and loop?
    1 / 1

    In JavaScript, you can play audio files using the Audio object. Here's how you could play and loop a .wav file:

    javascript
    let audio = new Audio('path/to/your/audio.wav');
audio.loop = true;
audio.play();

    Just replace 'path/to/your/audio.wav' with the actual path to your .wav file.

    Remember, some browsers don't allow audio to play before the user interacts with the page. So, you might want to trigger the audio playback in response to a user action, such as clicking a button to start the game.

    However, if you're going to be using Phaser.js, it has its own audio management system. Here's how you can play a looping sound with Phaser:

    First, you load the audio file in the preload() method of your scene:

    javascript
    this.load.audio('battleMusic', 'path/to/your/audio.wav');

    Then you can play the audio in create() method:

    javascript
    let music = this.sound.add('battleMusic');
music.play({ loop: true });

    Just like before, replace 'path/to/your/audio.wav' with the actual path to your .wav file. The { loop: true } part tells Phaser to loop the audio.

    Ok, how can I add controls to adjust the volume of the music and turn it on and off?
    1 / 1

    You can do this by adding a couple of HTML controls and handling their behavior in JavaScript. Here's an example:

    HTML:

    html
    <button id="toggle-music">Toggle Music</button>
<input type="range" id="volume-slider" min="0" max="1" step="0.01" value="1">

    JavaScript:

    javascript
    var music = new Audio('music.wav');
music.loop = true;
music.play();

document.getElementById("toggle-music").addEventListener("click", function() {
    if(music.paused) {
        music.play();
    } else {
        music.pause();
    }
});

document.getElementById("volume-slider").addEventListener("input", function() {
    music.volume = this.value;
});

    In this code, toggle-music is a button that toggles the music on and off each time it's clicked. volume-slider is a range input that controls the volume of the music. It's set to range from 0 to 1 because the volume property of an Audio object in JavaScript also ranges from 0 to 1.

    The addEventListener methods attach event listeners to the HTML elements. The "click" event on the button toggles the music on and off, and the "input" event on the range slider adjusts the volume.

    Please note that due to restrictions in some browsers, it might be necessary to start playing the audio in response to a user interaction, like a click event. The above example assumes the audio can start playing automatically, but you may need to adjust this depending on your specific situation and the browsers you're targeting.

    Ok, that all works. How can I add a sound effect when hovering over a button? Here's existing hover CSS: .actions button:hover { background-color: white; color: black; border: 2px solid #4CAF50; }
    1 / 1

    CSS can't play sound effects, but you can use JavaScript's onmouseover event to play a sound effect when the user hovers over a button.

    Here's how you can do it:

    1. First, include the sound file in your project, similar to how you added the background music. Here's an example using an MP3 file, but you can replace it with the format of your choice:
    html
    <audio id="hover-sound" src="hover-sound.mp3" preload="auto"></audio>
    1. Then, assign the onmouseover event to your buttons. You can use the querySelectorAll method to select all buttons and then loop through them to assign the event. Here's an example:
    javascript
    let buttons = document.querySelectorAll('.actions button');

buttons.forEach(button => {
    button.onmouseover = function() {
        let sound = document.getElementById('hover-sound');
        sound.play();
    };
});

    This code will play the sound effect every time the mouse cursor hovers over any button in the .actions class.

    Remember to control the volume of the hover sound as it can be annoying to users if it's too loud or plays too frequently. You can adjust the volume (a value between 0.0 and 1.0) with sound.volume = 0.5; for example.

    1 / 1
    Huh. Why are we using HTML audio tags here when we used let music = new Audio('battle-music.wav'); for the background music?
    1 / 1

    Both methods can be used to play audio in a web page, and both have their own use cases:

    1. HTML Audio Element: If you declare your audio file in the HTML using the <audio> tag, the audio file is downloaded when the page loads (or according to the "preload" attribute), and is ready to be played when the event (in your case, the mouse hover) occurs. This is useful if you have a small audio file that you want to be ready as soon as possible.

    2. JavaScript Audio Object: The new Audio() method in JavaScript is used to create a new HTMLAudioElement instance, which can be manipulated with JavaScript to play, pause, etc. This doesn't require you to place an <audio> tag in your HTML, making your HTML cleaner. The audio file is downloaded when the Audio object is created in JavaScript.

    In your case, you can use either method to achieve the same result. If you prefer to use the JavaScript Audio Object like you did with the background music, you could do something like:

    javascript
    let hoverSound = new Audio('hover-sound.mp3');

let buttons = document.querySelectorAll('.actions button');

buttons.forEach(button => {
    button.onmouseover = function() {
        hoverSound.play();
    };
});

    This will give you the same result as the previous example. The hover sound will be downloaded when the Audio object is created, not when the page loads.

    1 / 1
    And where should the HTML audio tags be placed? In the Head or Body?
    1 / 1

    The <audio> tags should ideally be placed in the body of your HTML document. Here's why:

    • The head of an HTML document is meant for meta-information about the document, like character encoding, linked stylesheets or scripts, meta tags, etc.

    • The body of an HTML document is where the content that is visible on the page in a browser is placed. This includes text, images, video, audio, and other multimedia content.

    The <audio> tag creates an audio player in the HTML document, which can be visible or invisible based on the controls attribute, so it's considered as part of the content of the web page and is typically placed in the body.

    However, if you do not want the audio player to be visible or interactable, and you just want the audio for playing sound effects or background music, you can place the <audio> tag anywhere in the body and it won't matter much because it won't be displayed. But it's a good practice to put it where it's semantically correct - in the body.

    Ok, I'm having a small issue. I get the following error: attackButton.onmouseover = function() { hoverSound.play(); }; Is this because I declare: let hoverSound = new Audio('retro_UI_hover.wav'); after I use hoverSound in a function?
    1 / 1

    Yes, that's exactly the problem. In JavaScript, code is executed from top to bottom, meaning it reads and processes code line by line from the start to the finish of a script file. If you attempt to use a variable before it's defined, JavaScript will throw an error because it doesn't yet know what that variable is supposed to represent.

    So you must define the hoverSound variable before you use it in the onmouseover event listener function. The following code will work correctly:

    javascript
    let hoverSound = new Audio('retro_UI_hover.wav');

attackButton.onmouseover = function() {
  hoverSound.play();
};

    In this code, hoverSound is defined before it's used, so JavaScript knows what it is and can use it appropriately.

    Can you tell me why this line is throwing an error? async this.opponent.monsters.forEach((monster) => {
    1 / 1

    In JavaScript, the async keyword is used to define an asynchronous function. It can be used in front of a function declaration, function expression, or an arrow function.

    However, it cannot be used in front of a method call or an array method such as forEach(). The forEach method operates synchronously and does not return a promise, so you can't directly make it asynchronous using async.

    If you want to use async with forEach, you would need to do it inside the function you're passing to forEach, not in front of forEach itself.

    This would look something like:

    javascript
    this.opponent.monsters.forEach(async (monster) => {
  // your asynchronous code
});

    But it's important to note that forEach won't wait for promises to resolve before moving on to the next item in the array.

    If you want to loop over an array and perform asynchronous operations in sequence (i.e., wait for each operation to complete before starting the next), you should use a for...of loop with async/await instead of forEach. Here's how it looks:

    javascript
    for (const monster of this.opponent.monsters) {
  await asyncFunction(monster);
}

    In the above code, asyncFunction(monster) is a placeholder for whatever asynchronous operation you want to perform.

    1 / 1
    I'm a little bit confused about how promises are working in my code. So, for example, in this code snippet, updateHpBar() returns a promise after 1500 milliseconds. Yet, it seems like the lines after the if else statement get executed prior to that. Can you explain this to me? if (this.opponent === this.player1) { await updateHpBar( "player1", activeMonster.currentHp, activeMonster.maxHp ); } else { await updateHpBar( "player2", activeMonster.currentHp, activeMonster.maxHp ); }
    1 / 1

    JavaScript uses an event-driven, non-blocking I/O model, meaning it can do other things without stopping the execution of your code.

    When you're using promises, it doesn't mean JavaScript will wait for the promise to resolve or reject before moving on to the next line of code. When a Promise is called, JavaScript will start its execution and then move on to the next line of code without waiting for the promise to finish.

    However, the await keyword changes this behavior. await will actually pause the execution of the function and wait for the promise to resolve or reject. But it's important to understand that it only pauses the execution of the current async function. This means that only the code after the await statement inside the same function will wait for the promise.

    So in your case:

    javascript
    if (this.opponent === this.player1) {
  await updateHpBar(
    "player1",
    activeMonster.currentHp,
    activeMonster.maxHp
  );
} else {
  await updateHpBar(
    "player2",
    activeMonster.currentHp,
    activeMonster.maxHp
  );
}

    After calling updateHpBar() with await, the JavaScript engine will pause the execution of this particular function until the promise returned by updateHpBar() is either resolved or rejected. Only after the promise is settled will the code execution continue from the point where it left off.

    However, any code outside this function (or even inside the same function but not after the await statement) won't be affected by this await statement and will continue executing. This is how JavaScript maintains its non-blocking nature even when we use async/await.

    The power of async/await is that it makes asynchronous code look and behave a bit more like synchronous code, which can make it easier to understand and reason about. But under the hood, JavaScript is still using promises and its non-blocking model.

    In conclusion, you're correct in observing that lines of code after the if...else statement get executed prior to the updateHpBar() function completing. This is because these lines of code are outside the async function that's awaiting the updateHpBar() call, and therefore, they don't get blocked by the await.

    Ok, so in this code, will the actions within if (monster.isFainted()) { ... } execute before the promise is returned? this.opponent.monsters.forEach(async (monster) => { if (!monster.fainted) { let damageTaken = monster.takeDamage(move.power, attackingMonster); console.log(`${monster.name} took ${damageTaken}!`) if (this.opponent === this.player1) { await updateHpBar( "player1", activeMonster.currentHp, activeMonster.maxHp ); } else { await updateHpBar( "player2", activeMonster.currentHp, activeMonster.maxHp ); } if (monster.isFainted()) { displayMessage(`${monster.name} fainted!`); monster.fainted = true; console.log("Current active before:" + this.opponent.currentMonster.name) if (this.opponent.activeMonster() === null) { winner = this.currentTurn.name; } } }
    1 / 1

    Your code currently does the following:

    1. For each monster, it executes the function which is marked as async because you are using the async keyword in front of the function definition within forEach.
    2. If the monster hasn't fainted, it takes damage and then updates the HP bar. Here, you're using await which means JavaScript will pause at this point and wait for updateHpBar to complete before moving to the next line in the function.
    3. Once updateHpBar resolves, then the code checks if the monster has fainted and if so, displays a message and sets the monster's fainted property to true.

    In this sense, yes, the actions within if (monster.isFainted()) { ... } will be executed after the promise returned by updateHpBar has been resolved.

    However, forEach doesn't play well with async/await. forEach will not wait for your promises to resolve before moving on to the next item in the array. This means that if you have multiple monsters, the updates and checks for each one may not happen in the order you're expecting.

    If you need to execute your operations in sequence (i.e., wait for the async operation for the first monster to finish before moving onto the second monster), you should use a for...of loop instead of forEach.

    Here's how you could write it:

    javascript
    for (const monster of this.opponent.monsters) {
  if (!monster.fainted) {
    let damageTaken = monster.takeDamage(move.power, attackingMonster);
    console.log(`${monster.name} took ${damageTaken}!`)
    if (this.opponent === this.player1) {
      await updateHpBar(
        "player1",
        activeMonster.currentHp,
        activeMonster.maxHp
      );
    } else {
      await updateHpBar(
        "player2",
        activeMonster.currentHp,
        activeMonster.maxHp
      );
    }
    if (monster.isFainted()) {
      displayMessage(`${monster.name} fainted!`);
      monster.fainted = true;
      console.log("Current active before:" + this.opponent.currentMonster.name)
      if (this.opponent.activeMonster() === null) {
        winner = this.currentTurn.name;
      }
    }
  }
}

    This will ensure that each monster is processed fully before moving onto the next one. The for...of loop respects async/await and will pause its iteration for each await statement.

    If you want to have dynamic text on top of the image button, you can wrap the image and text inside a div and position the text on top of the image. For changing the image on hover and click, you'll need to use JavaScript to change the image source. Here's how you can do it:

    For the HTML, structure your button like this:

    html
    <div class="menu-button" id="attack-button">
    <img src="path/to/normal-image.png" alt="Attack">
    <span>Attack</span>
</div>

    For the CSS, use something like this:

    css
    .menu-button {
    position: relative;
    display: inline-block;
    cursor: pointer;
}

.menu-button img {
    display: block;
    width: 100%;
    height: auto;
}

.menu-button span {
    position: absolute;
    top: 50%;
    left: 50%;
    transform: translate(-50%, -50%);
    color: white;
    font-size: 16px;
}

    In your JavaScript, add event listeners to change the image source:

    javascript
    let attackButton = document.getElementById('attack-button');

attackButton.addEventListener('mouseover', function() {
    this.children[0].src = "path/to/hover-image.png";
});

attackButton.addEventListener('mouseout', function() {
    this.children[0].src = "path/to/normal-image.png";
});

attackButton.addEventListener('mousedown', function() {
    this.children[0].src = "path/to/click-image.png";
});

attackButton.addEventListener('mouseup', function() {
    this.children[0].src = "path/to/hover-image.png";
});

    This code listens for mouseover, mouseout, mousedown, and mouseup events and changes the image source accordingly. Replace "path/to/hover-image.png" and "path/to/click-image.png" with the actual paths to your images. You can repeat this process for each of your buttons, changing the element id and image paths as necessary.

    The CSS property position: absolute positions an element relative to its nearest positioned ancestor. In this case, your span text is positioned relative to your .menu-button div. However, if no positioned ancestors are found, it will position relative to the document body, which could explain why your buttons ended up in the corner.

    One possible solution is to add a positioning context to your .menu-button class by giving it a position: relative;. This way, your text (and the image, if you've set that to absolute as well) will position relative to the button container. Here's an example:

    css
    .menu-button {
    position: relative;
    display: inline-block;
    cursor: pointer;
}

    Remember, position: relative on the parent element (.menu-button) doesn't move the element itself, but it enables absolute positioning for child elements. Now, when you set position: absolute; for the child elements (the img and span inside the .menu-button), they will position relative to the .menu-button container, not the whole document.

    You can add two event listeners for mouseover and mouseout to change the image source when the mouse hovers over the button and reverts it when the mouse leaves. For the click action, you can change the image source when the button is clicked, and then revert it back to the normal state when the action is done. Here's how you can do it:

    javascript
    const attackButton = document.getElementById("attack-button");

// Store paths to your images in variables for easy reference
let normalImage = "path_to_normal_image.png";
let hoverImage = "path_to_hover_image.png";
let clickImage = "path_to_click_image.png";

// Add an event listener for mouseover (hover)
attackButton.addEventListener("mouseover", function() {
  this.src = hoverImage; // Change the image to hoverImage when the mouse hovers over the button
  hoverSound.play();
});

// Add an event listener for mouseout
attackButton.addEventListener("mouseout", function() {
  this.src = normalImage; // Change the image back to normalImage when the mouse leaves the button
});

// Add an event listener for click
attackButton.addEventListener("click", function() {
  this.src = clickImage; // Change the image to clickImage when the button is clicked
  showAttackMenu();
  // Optionally, you can set a timeout to revert the image back to normal after a delay
  setTimeout(() => {
    this.src = normalImage;
  }, 500); // Change the image back to normalImage after 500ms
});

    Remember to replace "path_to_normal_image.png", "path_to_hover_image.png", and "path_to_click_image.png" with the actual paths to your images.

    So that doesn't work, but if I use this.children[0].src it does work. Why is that?
    1 / 1

    The reason that this.children[0].src works is because when you're using this in the context of the event handler, it's referring to the HTML button element you attached the event to. However, the src attribute doesn't apply to a button element, but to an img element.

    In your updated HTML, each button contains a single child element which is an img tag. So when you say this.children[0].src, you're actually referring to the src attribute of the img element that's the child of the button element.

    In short, this in your event listener refers to the button itself, and this.children[0] refers to the first (and in this case, only) child of the button, which is the img element. That's why this.children[0].src works to change the source of the image on the button.

    You can define a function to set up these event listeners and use it for all your buttons. Here's how you can do it:

    javascript
    function setupButton(buttonId, callback) {
  const button = document.getElementById(buttonId);
  
  button.addEventListener("mouseover", function() {
    this.children[0].src = hoverButton; // Change the image to hoverImage when the mouse hovers over the button
    hoverSound.play();
  });

  button.addEventListener("mouseout", function() {
    this.children[0].src = normalButton; // Change the image back to normalImage when the mouse leaves the button
  });

  button.addEventListener("click", async function() {
    this.children[0].src = clickButton; // Change the image to clickImage when the button is clicked
    await sleep(200);
    callback();
  });
}

// Set up the attack button
setupButton("attack-button", showAttackMenu);
// Set up the switch button
setupButton("switch-button", showSwitchMenu);
// Set up the item button
setupButton("item-button", showItemMenu);
// Set up the flee button
setupButton("flee-button", showFleeMenu);

    In this function, buttonId is the ID of the button you want to set up and callback is the function you want to execute when the button is clicked. You can then use this function for each of your buttons, passing in the appropriate ID and callback function.

    Just like in the previous function, you can modify the onmouseover and onclick properties within each button. Instead of setting the innerText, you will now create a span for the text and an img for the button's image, then append these elements to the button.

    Here is how to modify the showAttackMenu function:

    javascript
    function showAttackMenu() {
  clickSound.play();
  const attackMenu = document.getElementById("main-menu");
  const attacks = battle.currentTurn.currentMonster.moves;
  // Clear out the existing menu
  attackMenu.innerHTML = "";
  // Clear out existing buttons
  buttons = [];
  // For each attack, create a button, add the onclick, and append it to the menu
  attacks.forEach((attack) => {
    let attackButton = document.createElement("div");
    attackButton.className = 'actions';

    let attackImg = document.createElement('img');
    attackImg.src = normalButton;
    attackButton.appendChild(attackImg);

    let attackText = document.createElement('span');
    attackText.innerText = `${attack.name}, ${attack.currentUsage}/${attack.maxUsage}`;
    attackButton.appendChild(attackText);

    attackButton.addEventListener("mouseover", function() {
      hoverSound.play();
      this.children[0].src = hoverButton;
    });
    attackButton.addEventListener("mouseout", function() {
      this.children[0].src = normalButton;
    });
    attackButton.addEventListener("click", async function () {
      attackSound.play();
      if (attack.isUsable()) {
        this.children[0].src = clickButton;
        await sleep(200);
        attack.use();
        disableButtons();
        handleAttack(attack);
      } else {
        displayMessage("You can't use that move anymore.");
      }
    });

    attackMenu.appendChild(attackButton);
    buttons.push(attackButton);
  });
  let backButton = document.createElement("div");
  backButton.className = 'actions';

  let backImg = document.createElement('img');
  backImg.src = normalButton;
  backButton.appendChild(backImg);

  let backText = document.createElement('span');
  backText.innerText = "Back";
  backButton.appendChild(backText);

  backButton.addEventListener("mouseover", function() {
    hoverSound.play();
    this.children[0].src = hoverButton;
  });
  backButton.addEventListener("mouseout", function() {
    this.children[0].src = normalButton;
  });
  backButton.addEventListener("click", async function () {
    clickSound.play();
    this.children[0].src = clickButton;
    await sleep(200);
    showMainMenu();
  });

  attackMenu.appendChild(backButton);
  buttons.push(backButton);
}

    This modified function creates new buttons (div elements with class 'actions') and assigns the appropriate hover, click and mouseout events to each button. For the attack buttons, the onclick function checks if the attack is usable before using it. The Back button is also updated to display an image and text, and is appended to the attack menu at the end. The list of buttons is then updated with these new elements.

    Hmmm... this seems very complicated. Is it possible to establish a class or other structure that will automatically assign all of these functions to any button within main-menu or through some other method?

    Yes, it's possible to define a class and automatically assign these properties. However, JavaScript does not natively support classes for elements, so the "class" is more of a function that creates an element with the specified properties.

    Here's an example of how you can create a Button class:

    javascript
    class Button {
  constructor(text, hoverImage, clickImage, normalImage, mouseoverSound, clickSound, action) {
    this.element = document.createElement("div");
    this.element.className = 'actions';

    let img = document.createElement('img');
    img.src = normalImage;
    this.element.appendChild(img);

    let span = document.createElement('span');
    span.innerText = text;
    this.element.appendChild(span);

    this.element.addEventListener("mouseover", function() {
      mouseoverSound.play();
      this.children[0].src = hoverImage;
    });

    this.element.addEventListener("mouseout", function() {
      this.children[0].src = normalImage;
    });

    this.element.addEventListener("click", async function () {
      clickSound.play();
      this.children[0].src = clickImage;
      await sleep(200);
      action();
    });
  }
}

    You can create a new Button object and append it to the main menu like this:

    javascript
    let attackButton = new Button(`${attack.name}, ${attack.currentUsage}/${attack.maxUsage}`, hoverButton, clickButton, normalButton, hoverSound, attackSound, function() {
  if (attack.isUsable()) {
    attack.use();
    disableButtons();
    handleAttack(attack);
  } else {
    displayMessage("You can't use that move anymore.");
  }
});

attackMenu.appendChild(attackButton.element);

    Similarly for the backButton:

    javascript
    let backButton = new Button("Back", hoverButton, clickButton, normalButton, hoverSound, clickSound, showMainMenu);
attackMenu.appendChild(backButton.element);

    This way, you encapsulate the button creation process inside a class, which greatly simplifies your code and makes it easier to read and maintain. Note that hoverImage, clickImage, normalImage, mouseoverSound, clickSound, and action are parameters that need to be passed when creating a new Button object. The action parameter is a function that will be called when the button is clicked.

    Ok, how do I do this: You might also need to adjust your MenuButton CSS to apply the pointer-events rule to the button element instead of the div if you want the buttons to be non-interactive when disabled.
    1 / 1

    If you want to ensure that the button is non-interactive when it's disabled, you can use the pointer-events CSS property. It specifies under what circumstances a particular graphic element can become the target of pointer events.

    You can add a CSS rule to your stylesheet that will disable pointer events on disabled buttons. This way, even if the button is visually disabled, it will not respond to any pointer events, such as hovering or clicking.

    Add this to your CSS:

    css
    .menu-button > button:disabled {
  pointer-events: none;
}

    The above CSS rule will apply the pointer-events: none style to any button that is a direct child of an element with class menu-button and is in a disabled state.

    The :disabled pseudo-class is a CSS selector that selects all disabled elements. The pointer-events: none; property tells the browser to ignore all pointer events on the selected elements. Therefore, a disabled button will not be able to be clicked or triggered by a mouse event.

    I apologize for the confusion. If you're using a div element with nested img and span elements to represent each button, then the HTML disabled attribute and the CSS :disabled pseudo-class won't work, as these are specifically for form control elements like button, input, etc.

    However, you can still achieve the desired behavior with a custom approach. Here's a modified version of the MenuButton class and the disableButtons() function:

    javascript
    class MenuButton {
  constructor(id, name, onClickFunction) {
    // Create the outer div
    this.element = document.createElement('div');
    this.element.className = 'actions';
    this.element.id = id;
    
    // Create the image element
    this.imageElement = document.createElement('img');
    this.imageElement.src = normalButton;
    this.element.appendChild(this.imageElement);
    
    // Create the span element
    this.textElement = document.createElement('span');
    this.textElement.textContent = name;
    this.element.appendChild(this.textElement);

    this.element.onclick = () => {
      if (!this.disabled) {
        onClickFunction();
      }
    };

    this.element.onmouseover = () => {
      if (!this.disabled) {
        this.imageElement.src = hoverButton;
        hoverSound.play();
      }
    };

    this.element.onmouseout = () => {
      if (!this.disabled) {
        this.imageElement.src = normalButton;
      }
    };
    
    this.disabled = false;
  }

  disable() {
    this.disabled = true;
    this.imageElement.src = disabledButton; // Set the source to a disabled button image
  }

  enable() {
    this.disabled = false;
    this.imageElement.src = normalButton; // Reset the source to the normal button image
  }
}

function disableButtons() {
  buttons.forEach(button => button.disable());
}

    In this approach, we're adding a disabled property to the MenuButton class. This property is checked before responding to click or hover events, and is set to true when the disable() method is called. This won't prevent the click event from firing, but it will prevent your custom click behavior from running.

    We're also adding a disable() method that sets the disabled property to true and changes the button image to a "disabled" version (you'll need to provide a suitable image file and assign its URL to the disabledButton variable). The enable() method resets these properties.

    Then, in the disableButtons() function, we call the disable() method on each button. Note that you'll also need to modify your enableButtons() function to use the new enable() method:

    javascript
    function enableButtons() {
  buttons.forEach(button => button.enable());
}

    Finally, you should also adjust the CSS so that disabled buttons have a lower opacity (or other styling) to visually indicate their disabled status. To do this, you can add a CSS class in the disable() method and remove it in the enable() method:

    javascript
    this.element.classList.add('disabled');

this.element.classList.remove('disabled');

    And in your CSS:

    css
    .actions.disabled {
  opacity: 0.5;
  /* or other styling as desired */
}

    So the mouseover handler actually looks like this, using addEventListener: this.element.addEventListener("mouseover", function() { if (!this.disabled) { mouseoverSound.play(); this.children[0].src = hoverImage; } });
    1 / 1

    I see. The issue here is related to the usage of this within the callback function for addEventListener. In a callback function, this doesn't refer to the instance of the class (MenuButton) but rather the target of the event (the element the event is attached to).

    In this case, this.disabled in the callback doesn't refer to MenuButton.disabled but rather to HTMLDivElement.disabled (as the event listener is attached to a div), which isn't what you want.

    You have two ways to resolve this:

    Option 1: Using an arrow function Arrow functions preserve the value of this from the enclosing context, allowing you to access properties of the MenuButton instance:

    javascript
    this.element.addEventListener("mouseover", () => {
  if (!this.disabled) {
    mouseoverSound.play();
    this.imageElement.src = hoverImage;
  }
});

    Option 2: Binding this to the function You can bind the value of this to the callback function when you add the event listener:

    javascript
    this.element.addEventListener("mouseover", function() {
  if (!this.disabled) {
    mouseoverSound.play();
    this.imageElement.src = hoverImage;
  }
}.bind(this));

    Both options have the same result, so you can choose the one that fits your coding style best.

    If you choose the first option, remember to change all your callback functions to arrow functions to ensure this always refers to the MenuButton instance.

    Is there any reason I can't switch to your previous suggestion, using: this.element.onmouseover = () => { if (!this.disabled) { this.imageElement.src = hoverButton; hoverSound.play(); } }; ?
    1 / 1

    Yes, you can definitely use onmouseover with an arrow function. Here's how:

    javascript
    this.element.onmouseover = () => {
  if (!this.disabled) {
    this.imageElement.src = hoverButton;
    hoverSound.play();
  }
};

    The choice between using addEventListener and onmouseover often depends on the specific requirements of your application.

    addEventListener allows you to add multiple event handlers to the same event, which can be useful in complex applications where different parts of the code might need to respond to the same event. However, addEventListener might be more than you need for simple applications.

    On the other hand, onmouseover only allows you to set a single event handler for the mouseover event. If you assign a new function to onmouseover, it will overwrite any function that was previously assigned to it. But if you only need to set a single event handler, onmouseover can be simpler and more straightforward to use.

    Both approaches are valid, and you can choose the one that best fits your needs.

    Yes, you're correct! There's no property imageElement on your Button class. We need to replace this with img that you have defined in the constructor and save it as a property of the class.

    Modify your Button class like so:

    javascript
    class Button {
  constructor(text, hoverImage, clickImage, normalImage, mouseoverSound, clickSound, action) {
    this.element = document.createElement("div");
    this.element.className = 'actions';

    this.imageElement = document.createElement('img'); // Change this line
    this.imageElement.src = normalImage;
    this.element.appendChild(this.imageElement);

    let span = document.createElement('span');
    span.innerText = text;
    this.element.appendChild(span);

    this.element.addEventListener("mouseover", function() {
      if (!this.disabled) {
        mouseoverSound.play();
        this.imageElement.src = hoverImage; // Change this line
        console.log(this);
      }
    }.bind(this));

    this.element.addEventListener("mouseout", function() {
      if (!this.disabled) {
        this.imageElement.src = normalImage; // Change this line
      }
    }.bind(this));

    this.element.addEventListener("click", async function () {
      if (!this.disabled) {
        clickSound.play();
        this.imageElement.src = clickImage; // Change this line
        await sleep(200);
        this.imageElement.src = normalImage; // Change this line
        action();
      }
    }.bind(this));

    this.disabled = false;
  }

  disable() {
    this.disabled = true;
    this.imageElement.src = disabledButton; // Change this line
  }

  enable() {
    this.disabled = false;
    this.imageElement.src = normalButton; // Change this line
  }
}

    This should solve your problem with the image not changing on hover. The img element is now saved as a property of the class so you can reference it in your event handlers.

    1 / 1

    Yes, you can add a Promise return to a function by having it return a function that itself returns a Promise.

    The function sleep(ms) you defined returns a Promise that resolves after a certain amount of milliseconds. If you use return sleep(ms); at the end of your battle.handleSwitch(option); function, it means handleSwitch will now return a Promise that resolves after ms milliseconds.

    However, it's important to note that just sleeping for 1 millisecond (sleep(1)) is almost instantaneous, so it might not have the effect you're expecting unless the handleSwitch function has some asynchronous operations that take a significant amount of time. If you're trying to allow some time for animations or other updates to take place, you might need a longer sleep duration.

    Remember also that await can only be used inside an async function. So ensure the function in which you're calling await battle.handleSwitch(option); is an async function. I noticed in your code snippet you've correctly made the function async.

    In your use case, if battle.handleSwitch(option); has asynchronous operations (like server calls, reading files, waiting for user input, etc.), you need to make handleSwitch an async function and use await before these operations. This way, handleSwitch will return a Promise that will resolve only when all the asynchronous operations within it have completed. This is a better practice compared to returning sleep(1), which doesn't take into account the actual completion of asynchronous operations within handleSwitch.

    1 / 1

    forEach is a method of JavaScript arrays. It is used to execute a provided function on each element of the array.

    And yes, asynchronous functions and forEach can have some complications. The forEach method does not wait for promises. So if you're trying to run asynchronous operations in sequence (i.e., wait for one to complete before starting the next), forEach may not behave as expected.

    In your case, it should not affect the execution of handleSwitch(option) and updating the button's text, since these operations are encapsulated within the button click event and do not depend on the forEach loop.

    However, if there are other asynchronous operations in the loop that you want to run in sequence, or if you want to wait until all the asynchronous operations have completed before moving on to the next part of your code, you might want to use for...of loop or Promise.all instead of forEach.

    Here's how you could use for...of:

    javascript
    for (const option of switchOptions) {
  let switchButton = new Button(`${option.name} ${option.currentHp}/${option.maxHp}`, hoverButton, clickButton, normalButton, hoverSound, clickSound, async function() {
    await battle.handleSwitch(option);
    switchButton.textElement.innerText = `${option.name} ${option.currentHp}/${option.maxHp}`;
  })
  switchMenu.appendChild(switchButton.element);
  buttons.push(switchButton);
}

    And Promise.all:

    javascript
    await Promise.all(switchOptions.map(async (option) => {
  let switchButton = new Button(`${option.name} ${option.currentHp}/${option.maxHp}`, hoverButton, clickButton, normalButton, hoverSound, clickSound, async function() {
    await battle.handleSwitch(option);
    switchButton.textElement.innerText = `${option.name} ${option.currentHp}/${option.maxHp}`;
  })
  switchMenu.appendChild(switchButton.element);
  buttons.push(switchButton);
}));

    But again, in your specific case, the forEach loop should not be causing any issues with battle.handleSwitch(option) or the updating of the button text.

    If the main purpose of your function is to update the HP displayed on the buttons, it would be best to directly tie each button to its corresponding monster. This way, you avoid issues with having to manage an external "incrementor" and make sure the indices align correctly.

    If you stored a reference to the monster object in your Button class, you could update the button text directly based on the current HP of the monster. Here's how you might implement this:

    javascript
    class Button {
  constructor(text, hoverImage, clickImage, normalImage, mouseoverSound, clickSound, action, linkedObject) {
    //...
    this.linkedObject = linkedObject; // This would be the monster in your case
    //...
  }
  
  updateText() {
    if (this.linkedObject) {
      this.textElement.innerText = `${this.linkedObject.name} ${this.linkedObject.currentHp}/${this.linkedObject.maxHp}`;
    }
  }
}

//...
// Then, when creating the button:
let switchButton = new Button(`${option.name} ${option.currentHp}/${option.maxHp}`, hoverButton, clickButton, normalButton, hoverSound, clickSound, async function() {
  await battle.handleSwitch(option);
}, option);
//...
// And when updating the HP
buttons.forEach(button => button.updateText());

    This approach ties the button directly to the object it represents, removing the need for the incrementor and making the relationship between buttons and monsters clearer. It also simplifies your update loop to just a single line.

    Note: Be careful with linking objects like this, as it can create memory leaks if you're not careful to clean up properly. However, in this case, it should be fine as the lifetime of the Button and the Monster it represents are likely tied together.

    That's a good point! To handle different types of buttons, you could pass a function to the Button class that knows how to properly format the text for that button type. Here's how you could do this:

    javascript
    class Button {
  constructor(text, hoverImage, clickImage, normalImage, mouseoverSound, clickSound, action, updateTextFunction) {
    //...

    //...
  }
  
  updateText() {
    if (this.updateTextFunction) {
      this.textElement.innerText = this.updateTextFunction();
    }
  }
}

//...
// Then, when creating the button:
let switchButton = new Button(
  `${option.name} ${option.currentHp}/${option.maxHp}`,
  hoverButton,
  clickButton,
  normalButton,
  hoverSound,
  clickSound,
  async function() {
    await battle.handleSwitch(option);
  },
  function() {
    return `${option.name} ${option.currentHp}/${option.maxHp}`;
  }
);

//...

// And when updating the HP
buttons.forEach(button => button.updateText());

    This approach makes your Button class more flexible to handle different types of buttons. The specific formatting of the button text is passed in when the button is created, so it can be customized based on the type of button.
